metadata.title: Right to left | Apple Developer Documentation

metadata.summary: Apple Developer Documentation page providing comprehensive guidelines for supporting right-to-left (RTL) languages like Arabic and Hebrew in app interfaces. The document covers text alignment, number systems, controls, images, and interface icons with detailed examples and platform considerations.

content.text: Right to left
Support right-to-left languages like Arabic and Hebrew by reversing your interface as needed to match the reading direction of the related scripts.
When people choose a language for their device — or just your app or game — they expect the interface to adapt in various ways (to learn more, see Localization).

System-provided UI frameworks support right-to-left (RTL) by default, allowing system-provided UI components to flip automatically in the RTL context. If you use system-provided elements and standard layouts, you might not need to make any changes to your app's automatically reversed interface.

If you want to fine-tune your layout or enhance specific localizations to adapt to different currencies, numerals, or mathematical symbols that can occur in various locales in countries that use RTL languages, follow these guidelines.
Text alignment

Adjust text alignment to match the interface direction, if the system doesn't do so automatically. For example, if you left-align text with content in the left-to-right (LTR) context, right-align the text to match the content's mirrored position in the RTL context.

content.description: Two side-by-side interface mockups showing text alignment differences. Left mockup shows left-aligned text with horizontal lines of varying lengths aligned to the left edge. Right mockup shows the same content mirrored with lines aligned to the right edge.
content.composition: Two rectangular interface mockups side by side, each containing horizontal gray lines representing text

captions.text: Left-aligned text in the LTR context
Right-aligned content in the RTL context

content.contextualRelevance: Visual demonstration of how text alignment should mirror when interface direction changes

content.text: Align a paragraph based on its language, not on the current context. When the alignment of a paragraph — defined as three or more lines of text — doesn't match its language, it can be difficult to read. For example, right-aligning a paragraph that consists of LTR text can make the beginning of each line difficult to see. To improve readability, continue aligning one- and two-line text blocks to match the reading direction of the current context, but align a paragraph to match its language.

content.description: Two interface mockups demonstrating paragraph alignment in RTL context. Left mockup shows a left-aligned paragraph (correct for LTR text in RTL interface). Right mockup shows a right-aligned paragraph (incorrect for LTR text).
content.composition: Two card mockups side by side with multiple lines of text represented by horizontal gray lines

A right-aligned paragraph in the RTL context

content.contextualRelevance: Shows that paragraphs should align based on their language, not the interface direction

content.text: Use a consistent alignment for all text items in a list. To ensure a comfortable reading and scanning experience, reverse the alignment of all items in a list, including items that are displayed in a different script.

content.description: Two list mockups side by side. Left shows consistent right-alignment of all list items in RTL context (correct). Right shows mixed alignment where some items are left-aligned and others right-aligned (incorrect).

content.text: Numbers and characters

Different RTL languages can use different number systems. For example, Hebrew text uses Western Arabic numerals, whereas Arabic text might use either Western or Eastern Arabic numerals. The use of Western and Eastern Arabic numerals varies among countries and regions and even among areas within the same country or region.

If your app covers mathematical concepts or other number-centric topics, it's a good idea to identify the appropriate way to display such information in each locale you support. In contrast, apps that don't address number-related topics can generally rely on system-provided number representations.

content.description: Two number displays showing the difference between Western Arabic numerals and Eastern Arabic numerals. Both show the same numeric value but in different numeral systems.
content.composition: Two horizontal display boxes showing numeric values

captions.text: Western Arabic numerals
Eastern Arabic numerals

content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates visual difference between Western and Eastern Arabic numeral systems

content.text: Don't reverse the order of numerals in a specific number. Regardless of the current language or the surrounding content, the digits in a specific number — such as "541," a phone number, or a credit card number — always appear in the same order.

content.description: Four interface mockups showing how phone numbers appear the same across different languages: Latin, Hebrew, Arabic with Western Arabic numerals, and Arabic with Eastern Arabic numerals. The digit order remains consistent.

content.text: Reverse the order of numerals that show progress or a counting direction; never flip the numerals themselves. Controls like progress bars, sliders, and rating controls often include numerals to clarify their meaning. If you use numerals in this way, be sure to reverse the order of the numerals to match the direction of the flipped control. Also reverse a sequence of numerals if you use the sequence to communicate a specific order.

content.text: Controls

Flip controls that show progress from one value to another. Because people tend to view forward progress as moving in the same direction as the language they read, it makes sense to flip controls like sliders and progress indicators in the RTL context. When you do this, also be sure to reverse the positions of the accompanying glyphs or images that depict the beginning and ending values of the control.

content.description: Two slider controls showing directional flip. Left shows LTR context with small icon on left, large icon on right. Right shows RTL context with icons reversed - large icon on left, small icon on right.
content.composition: Two horizontal slider mockups with icons at each end indicating minimum and maximum values

captions.text: A directional control in the LTR context
A directional control in the RTL context

content.contextualRelevance: Shows how progress controls and their accompanying icons should flip in RTL

content.text: Flip controls that help people navigate or access items in a fixed order. For example, in the RTL context, a back button must point to the right so the flow of screens matches the reading order of the RTL language. Similarly, next or previous buttons that let people access items in an ordered list need to flip in the RTL context to match the reading order.

Preserve the direction of a control that refers to an actual direction or points to an onscreen area. For example, if you provide a control that means "to the right," it must always point right, regardless of the current context.

Visually balance adjacent Latin and RTL scripts when necessary. In buttons, labels, and titles, Arabic or Hebrew text can appear too small when next to uppercased Latin text, because Arabic and Hebrew don't include uppercase letters. To visually balance Arabic or Hebrew text with Latin text that uses all capitals, it often works well to increase the RTL font size by about 2 points.

content.description: Two text comparison examples. Top shows Arabic and Hebrew text appearing too small next to uppercased Latin text at the same font size. Bottom shows the improved version where RTL text is slightly larger to create visual balance.
content.composition: Two rows of text samples showing before/after visual balancing

captions.text: Arabic and Hebrew text can look too small next to uppercased Latin text of the same font size.
You can slightly increase the font size of Arabic and Hebrew text to visually balance uppercased Latin text.

content.contextualRelevance: Demonstrates the visual balancing technique for mixed LTR/RTL text

content.text: Images

Avoid flipping images like photographs, illustrations, and general artwork. Flipping an image often changes the image's meaning; flipping a copyrighted image could be a violation. If an image's content is strongly connected to reading direction, consider creating a new version of the image instead of flipping the original.

Reverse the positions of images when their order is meaningful. For example, if you display multiple images in a specific order like chronological, alphabetical, or favorite, reverse their positions to preserve the order's meaning in the RTL context.

content.description: Two sets of image grid layouts. Left shows numbered images 1-2-3 in left-to-right order (LTR context). Right shows the same images in reversed 3-2-1 order for RTL context.
content.composition: Two horizontal rows of three placeholder images each, with numbers indicating order

captions.text: Items with meaningful positions in the LTR context
Items with meaningful positions in the RTL context

content.contextualRelevance: Shows how ordered image collections should reverse position (not flip) in RTL

content.text: Interface icons

When you use SF Symbols to supply interface icons for your app, you get variants for the RTL context and localized symbols for Arabic and Hebrew, among other languages. If you create custom symbols, you can specify their directionality. For developer guidance, see Creating custom symbol images for your app.

content.text: Flip interface icons that represent text or reading direction. For example, if an interface icon uses left-aligned bars to represent text in the LTR context, right-align the bars in the RTL context.

content.description: Two text-representation icons. Left shows horizontal lines aligned to left (representing LTR text). Right shows the same lines aligned to right (representing RTL text).

content.text: Consider creating a localized version of an interface icon that displays text. Some interface icons include letters or words to help communicate a script-related concept, like font-size choice or a signature. If you have a custom interface icon that needs to display actual text, consider creating a localized version. For example, SF Symbols offers different versions of the signature, rich-text, and I-beam pointer symbols for use with Latin, Hebrew, and Arabic text, among others.

content.description: Three localized versions of an icon showing text. Latin version with Latin letters, Hebrew version with Hebrew characters, Arabic version with Arabic characters.

captions.text: Latin
Hebrew
Arabic

content.contextualRelevance: Shows localized icon variants for different scripts

content.text: If you have a custom interface icon that uses letters or words to communicate a concept unrelated to reading or writing, consider designing an alternative image that doesn't use text.

Flip an interface icon that shows forward or backward motion. When something moves in the same direction that people read, they typically interpret that direction as forward; when something moves in the opposite direction, people tend to interpret the direction as backward. An interface icon that depicts an object moving forward or backward needs to flip in the RTL context to preserve the meaning of the motion. For example, an icon that represents a speaker typically shows sound waves emanating forward from the speaker. In the LTR context, the sound waves come from the left, so in the RTL context, the icon needs to flip to show the waves coming from the right.

content.description: Two speaker icons with sound waves. Left shows waves emanating to the right (LTR). Right shows icon flipped with waves emanating to the left (RTL).
content.composition: Two speaker icons side by side

captions.text: LTR variant of a symbol that depicts forward motion
RTL variant of a symbol that depicts forward motion

content.contextualRelevance: Shows how motion-indicating icons should flip to preserve meaning

content.text: Don't flip logos or universal signs and marks. Displaying a flipped logo confuses people and can have legal repercussions. Always display a logo in its original form, even if it includes text. People expect universal symbols and marks like the checkmark to have a consistent appearance, so avoid flipping them.

content.description: Two icons: a logo placeholder on the left, and a universal checkmark symbol on the right. Both should not be flipped.

captions.text: A logo
A universal symbol or mark

content.contextualRelevance: Shows examples of elements that should never be flipped

content.text: In general, avoid flipping interface icons that depict real-world objects. Unless you use the object to indicate directionality, it's best to avoid flipping an icon that represents a familiar item. For example, clocks work the same everywhere, so a traditional clock interface icon needs to look the same regardless of language direction. Some interface icons might seem to reference language or reading direction because they represent items that are slanted for right-handed use. However, most people are right-handed, so flipping an icon that shows a right-handed tool isn't necessary and might be confusing.

Before merely flipping a complex custom interface icon, consider its individual components and the overall visual balance. In some cases, a component — like a badge, slash, or magnifying glass — needs to adhere to a visual design language regardless of localization. For example, SF Symbols maintains visual consistency by using the same backslash to represent the prohibition or negation of a symbol's meaning in both LTR and RTL versions.

content.description: Two icons with prohibition backslashes. Both LTR and RTL versions maintain the same backslash orientation for visual consistency.
content.composition: Two icons side by side showing backslash consistency

captions.text: LTR variant of a symbol that includes a backslash
RTL variant of a symbol that includes a backslash

content.contextualRelevance: Shows how backslashes should remain consistent across localizations

content.text: In other cases, you might need to flip a component (or its position) to ensure the localized version of the icon still makes sense. For example, if a badge represents the actual UI that people see in your app, it needs to flip if your UI flips. Alternatively, if a badge modifies the meaning of an interface icon, consider whether flipping the badge preserves both the modified meaning and the overall visual balance of the icon. In the images shown below, the badge doesn't depict an object in the UI, but keeping it in the top-right corner visually unbalances the cart.
If your custom interface icon includes a component that can imply handedness, like a tool, consider preserving the orientation of the tool while flipping the base image if necessary.

content.description: Two icons showing a tool (like a pencil or pen). Both LTR and RTL versions preserve the tool's orientation for right-handed use.

captions.text: LTR variant of a symbol that depicts a tool
RTL variant of a symbol that depicts a tool

content.contextualRelevance: Shows how tools should maintain their orientation regardless of interface direction

No additional considerations for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, visionOS, or watchOS.

pages.pageSummary: Comprehensive Apple Human Interface Guidelines documentation page covering right-to-left (RTL) language support for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, visionOS, and watchOS. The page provides detailed guidance on text alignment, number systems, controls, images, and interface icons with specific recommendations for supporting Arabic, Hebrew, and other RTL languages.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.summary: Overview of RTL support explaining that system frameworks handle most RTL adaptations automatically, with guidelines for fine-tuning.

sections.title: Text alignment
sections.summary: Guidelines for aligning text in RTL contexts, including mirroring alignment with interface direction, aligning paragraphs based on language, and maintaining consistent list alignment.

sections.title: Numbers and characters
sections.summary: Guidance on handling different numeral systems (Western vs Eastern Arabic), when to preserve digit order, and when to reverse numeral sequences for progress indicators.

sections.title: Controls
sections.summary: Recommendations for flipping progress controls, navigation buttons, and directional controls while preserving actual directional references. Also covers visually balancing mixed scripts.

sections.title: Images
sections.summary: Guidance on not flipping photographs and artwork, but reversing positions of images when their order is meaningful.

sections.title: Interface icons
sections.summary: Detailed guidance on which icons to flip (text direction, forward motion) and which to preserve (logos, universal symbols, real-world objects, tools). Includes SF Symbols RTL support information.

sections.title: Platform considerations
sections.summary: Notes that no additional platform-specific considerations exist for iOS, iPadOS, macOS, tvOS, visionOS, or watchOS.

sections.title: Resources
sections.summary: Links to related documentation (Layout, Inclusion, SF Symbols, Localization), developer documentation (SwiftUI localization), and WWDC videos on multilingual design.

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document begins with an introduction explaining automatic RTL support in system frameworks, then systematically covers each aspect of RTL design: text alignment (with special attention to paragraphs vs short text), number systems and when to preserve vs reverse digit order, control behavior and directional meaning, image handling, and finally detailed interface icon guidelines covering multiple scenarios. The document concludes with platform considerations (none additional) and related resources.

introductionParagraphs: When people choose a language for their device — or just your app or game — they expect the interface to adapt in various ways (to learn more, see Localization).

textAlignment.heading: Text alignment

guidelines.text: Adjust text alignment to match the interface direction, if the system doesn't do so automatically. For example, if you left-align text with content in the left-to-right (LTR) context, right-align the text to match the content's mirrored position in the RTL context.

When the alignment of a paragraph — defined as three or more lines of text — doesn't match its language, it can be difficult to read. For example, right-aligning a paragraph that consists of LTR text can make the beginning of each line difficult to see. To improve readability, continue aligning one- and two-line text blocks to match the reading direction of the current context, but align a paragraph to match its language.

Use a consistent alignment for all text items in a list. To ensure a comfortable reading and scanning experience, reverse the alignment of all items in a list, including items that are displayed in a different script.

interfaceIcons.heading: Interface icons

If you have a custom interface icon that uses letters or words to communicate a concept unrelated to reading or writing, consider designing an alternative image that doesn't use text.

In other cases, you might need to flip a component (or its position) to ensure the localized version of the icon still makes sense. For example, if a badge represents the actual UI that people see in your app, it needs to flip if your UI flips. For example, clocks work the same everywhere, so a traditional clock interface icon needs to look the same regardless of language direction. However, most people are right-handed, so flipping an icon that shows a right-handed tool isn't necessary and might be confusing.
